svg.text: â€¢ Different return types (file paths vs URLs vs S3 keys)
â€¢ Different exception types and behaviors
â€¢ Client code breaks when switching providers
UploadDocumentAsync() â†’ Returns UploadResult with DocumentId
â€¢ Consistent return types and behaviors
â€¢ Client code works with any implementation
"Objects of a superclass should be replaceable with objects of its subclasses"
If you can't substitute a derived class for its base class, you're violating LSP
var content = await storage.DownloadDocumentAsync(id); // BREAKS! ğŸ’¥
// LocalStorage expects file path, gets URL
Any implementation can replace another without
breaking client code or changing behavior
Client depends on abstraction, not concretion
Consistent contracts and behaviors across all
Same exception types and error handling
Unit tests written for base class work for all
Changes in one implementation don't affect others
Refactoring is safer and more predictable
Easy to add new storage providers
âœ“ Derived classes must honor the contract of their base class
âœ“ Preconditions cannot be strengthened, postconditions cannot be weakened
âœ“ If you can't substitute derived for base, you're violating LSP
âœ“ Same exception types and behaviors across all implementations
âœ“ Consistent return types and method signatures
âœ“ Behavioral compatibility is more important than structural similarity
Liskov Substitution Principle - ASP.NET Core Document Storage API
